column2: Fairies and their like belong to every country and every age, and no doubt we should see plenty of them now--if we only knew how.
column3: Fairies and their like belong to every country and every age, and no doubt we should see plenty of them now-if we only knew how.

column2: In a large town in Germany there lived, some couple of hundred years ago, a cobbler and his wife.
column3: In a large town in Germany there lived, some couple of hundred years ago, a cobbler and his wife.

column2: They were poor and hard-working.
column3: They were poor and hard-working.

column2: The man sat all day in a little stall at the street corner and mended any shoes that were brought him.
column3: The man sat all day in a little stall at the street corner and mended any shoes that were brought him.

column2: His wife sold the fruit and vegetables they grew in their garden in the Market Place, and as she was always neat and clean and her goods were temptingly spread out she had plenty of customers.
column3: His wife sold the fruit and vegetables they grew in their garden in the Market Place, and as she was always neat and clean and her goods were temptingly spread out she had plenty of customers.

column2: The couple had one boy called Jem.
column3: The couple had one boy called Jem.

column2: He used to sit by his mother in the market and would carry home what people bought from her, for which they often gave him a pretty flower, or a slice of cake, or even some small coin.
column3: He used to sit by his mother in the market and would carry home what people bought from her, for which they often gave him a pretty flower, or a slice of cake, or even some small coin.

column2: One day Jem and his mother sat as usual in the Market Place with plenty of nice herbs and vegetables spread out on the board, and in some smaller baskets early pears, apples, and apricots.
column3: One day Jem and his mother sat as usual in the Market Place with plenty of nice herbs and vegetables spread out on the board, and in some smaller baskets early pears, apples, and apricots.

column2: Jem cried his wares at the top of his voice:
column3: Jem cried his wares at the top of his voice:

column2: 'This way, gentlemen!
column3: 'This way, gentlemen!

column2: See these lovely cabbages and these fresh herbs! Early apples, ladies; early pears and apricots, and all cheap.
column3: See these lovely cabbages and these fresh herbs! Early apples, ladies; early pears and apricots, and all cheap.

column2: Come, buy, buy!'
column3: Come, buy, buy!'

column2: As he cried an old woman came across the Market Place.
column3: As he cried an old woman came across the Market Place.

column2: In this fashion she came along till she got to the stall where Jem and his mother were, and there she stopped.
column3: In this fashion she came along till she got to the stall where Jem and his mother were, and there she stopped.

column2: 'Are you Hannah the herb seller?' she asked in a croaky voice as her head shook to and fro.
column3: 'Are you Hannah the herb seller?' she asked in a croaky voice as her head shook to and fro.

column2: 'Yes, I am,' was the answer.
column3: 'Yes, I am,' was the answer.

column2: 'Can I serve you?'
column3: 'Can I serve you?'

column2: Let me look at those herbs.
column3: Let me look at those herbs.

column2: I wonder if you've got what I want,' said the old woman as she thrust a pair of hideous brown hands into the herb basket, and began turning over all the neatly packed herbs with her skinny fingers, often holding them up to her nose and sniffing at them.
column3: I wonder if you've got what I want,' said the old woman as she thrust a pair of hideous brown hands into the herb basket, and began turning over all the neatly packed herbs with her skinny fingers, often holding them up to her nose and sniffing at them.

column2: The cobbler's wife felt much disgusted at seeing her wares treated like this, but she dared not speak.
column3: The cobbler's wife felt much disgusted at seeing her wares treated like this, but she dared not speak.

column2: When the old hag had turned over the whole basket she muttered, 'Bad stuff, bad stuff; much better fifty years ago--all bad.'
column3: When the old hag had turned over the whole basket she muttered, 'Bad stuff, bad stuff; much better fifty years ago-all bad.'

column2: This made Jem very angry
column3: This made Jem very angry

column2: 'You are a very rude old woman,' he cried out.
column3: 'You are a very rude old woman,' he cried out.

column2: 'First you mess all our nice herbs about with your horrid brown fingers and sniff at them with your long nose till no one else will care to buy them, and then you say it's all bad stuff, though the duke's cook himself buys all his herbs from us.'
column3: 'First you mess all our nice herbs about with your horrid brown fingers and sniff at them with your long nose till no one else will care to buy them, and then you say it's all bad stuff, though the duke's cook himself buys all his herbs from us.'

column2: The old woman looked sharply at the saucy boy, laughed unpleasantly, and said:
column3: The old woman looked sharply at the saucy boy, laughed unpleasantly, and said:

column2: 'So you don't like my long nose, sonny?
column3: 'So you don't like my long nose, sonny?

column2: Well, you shall have one yourself, right down to your chin.'
column3: Well, you shall have one yourself, right down to your chin.'

column2: As she spoke she shuffled towards the hamper of cabbages, took up one after another, squeezed them hard, and threw them back, muttering again, 'Bad stuff, bad stuff.'
column3: As she spoke she shuffled towards the hamper of cabbages, took up one after another, squeezed them hard, and threw them back, muttering again, 'Bad stuff, bad stuff.'

column2: 'Your neck is as thin as a cabbage-stalk, and it might easily break and your head fall into the basket, and then who would buy anything?'
column3: 'Your neck is as thin as a cabbage stalk, and it might easily break and your head fall into the basket, and then who would buy anything?'

column2: 'Then you sha'n't have any, but a head stuck close between your shoulders so that it may be quite sure not to fall off.'
column3: 'Then you sha'n't have any, but a head stuck close between your shoulders so that it may be quite sure not to fall off.'

column2: 'If you wish to buy, please make haste, as you are keeping other customers away.'
column3: 'If you wish to buy, please make haste, as you are keeping other customers away.'

column2: 'Very well, I will do as you ask,' said the old woman, with an angry look.
column3: 'Very well, I will do as you ask,' said the old woman, with an angry look.

column2: 'I will buy these six cabbages, but, as you see, I can only walk with my stick and can carry nothing.
column3: 'I will buy these six cabbages, but, as you see, I can only walk with my stick and can carry nothing.

column2: Let your boy carry them home for me and I'll pay him for his trouble.'
column3: Let your boy carry them home for me and I'll pay him for his trouble.'

column2: The little fellow didn't like this, and began to cry, for he was afraid of the old woman, but his mother ordered him to go, for she thought it wrong not to help such a weakly old creature; so, still crying, he gathered the cabbages into a basket and followed the old woman across the Market Place.
column3: The little fellow didn't like this, and began to cry, for he was afraid of the old woman, but his mother ordered him to go, for she thought it wrong not to help such a weakly old creature; so, still crying, he gathered the cabbages into a basket and followed the old woman across the Market Place.

column2: She drew a rusty old hook from her pocket and stuck it into a little hole in the door, which suddenly flew open.
column3: She drew a rusty old hook from her pocket and stuck it into a little hole in the door, which suddenly flew open.

column2: The house was splendidly furnished, the walls and ceiling of marble, the furniture of ebony inlaid with gold and precious stones, the floor of such smooth slippery glass that the little fellow tumbled down more than once.
column3: The house was splendidly furnished, the walls and ceiling of marble, the furniture of ebony inlaid with gold and precious stones, the floor of such smooth slippery glass that the little fellow tumbled down more than once.

column2: The old woman took out a silver whistle and blew it till the sound rang through the house.
column3: The old woman took out a silver whistle and blew it till the sound rang through the house.

column2: Immediately a lot of guinea pigs came running down the stairs, but Jem thought it rather odd that they all walked on their hind legs, wore nutshells for shoes, and men's clothes, whilst even their hats were put on in the newest fashion.
column3: Immediately a lot of guinea pigs came running down the stairs, but Jem thought it rather odd that they all walked on their hind legs, wore nutshells for shoes, and men's clothes, whilst even their hats were put on in the newest fashion.

column2: 'Where are my slippers, lazy crew?' cried the old woman, and hit about with her stick.
column3: 'Where are my slippers, lazy crew?' cried the old woman, and hit about with her stick.

column2: She threw away her stick and walked briskly across the glass floor, drawing little Jem after her.
column3: She threw away her stick and walked briskly across the glass floor, drawing little Jem after her.

column2: At last she paused in a room which looked almost like a kitchen, it was so full of pots and pans, but the tables were of mahogany and the sofas and chairs covered with the richest stuffs.
column3: At last she paused in a room which looked almost like a kitchen, it was so full of pots and pans, but the tables were of mahogany and the sofas and chairs covered with the richest stuffs.

column2: 'Sit down,' said the old woman pleasantly, and she pushed Jem into a corner of a sofa and put a table close in front of him.
column3: 'Sit down,' said the old woman pleasantly, and she pushed Jem into a corner of a sofa and put a table close in front of him.

column2: 'Sit down, you've had a long walk and a heavy load to carry, and I must give you something for your trouble.
column3: 'Sit down, you've had a long walk and a heavy load to carry, and I must give you something for your trouble.

column2: So saying, she whistled again.
column3: So saying, she whistled again.

column2: First came in guinea pigs in men's clothing.
column3: First came in guinea pigs in men's clothing.

column2: They had tied on large kitchen aprons, and in their belts were stuck carving knives and sauce ladles and such things.
column3: They had tied on large kitchen aprons, and in their belts were stuck carving knives and sauce ladles and such things.

column2: They too walked on their hind legs, wore full Turkish trousers, and little green velvet caps on their heads.
column3: They too walked on their hind legs, wore full Turkish trousers, and little green velvet caps on their heads.

column2: They seemed to be the scullions, for they clambered up the walls and brought down pots and pans, eggs, flour, butter, and herbs, which they carried to the stove.
column3: They seemed to be the scullions, for they clambered up the walls and brought down pots and pans, eggs, flour, butter, and herbs, which they carried to the stove.

column2: Here the old woman was bustling about, and Jem could see that she was cooking something very special for him.
column3: Here the old woman was bustling about, and Jem could see that she was cooking something very special for him.

column3: At last the broth began to bubble and boil, and she drew off the saucepan and poured its contents into a silver bowl, which she set before Jem.

column2: 'There, my boy,' said she, 'eat this soup and then you'll have everything which pleased you so much about me.
column3: 'There, my boy,' said she, 'eat this soup and then you'll have everything which pleased you so much about me.

column2: Why had your mother not got it in her basket?'
column3: Why had your mother not got it in her basket?'

column2: The child could not think what she was talking about, but he quite understood the soup, which tasted most delicious.

column2: His mother had often given him nice things, but nothing had ever seemed so good as this.
column3: His mother had often given him nice things, but nothing had ever seemed so good as this.

column2: The smell of the herbs and spices rose from the bowl, and the soup tasted both sweet and sharp at the same time, and was very strong.
column3: The smell of the herbs and spices rose from the bowl, and the soup tasted both sweet and sharp at the same time, and was very strong.

column2: As he was finishing it the guinea pigs lit some Arabian incense, which gradually filled the room with clouds of blue vapour.
column3: As he was finishing it the guinea pigs lit some Arabian incense, which gradually filled the room with clouds of blue vapour.

column2: They grew thicker and thicker and the scent nearly overpowered the boy.
column3: They grew thicker and thicker and the scent nearly overpowered the boy.

column2: He reminded himself that he must get back to his mother, but whenever he tried to rouse himself to go he sank back again drowsily, and at last he fell sound asleep in the corner of the sofa.
column3: He reminded himself that he must get back to his mother, but whenever he tried to rouse himself to go he sank back again drowsily, and at last he fell sound asleep in the corner of the sofa.

column2: Strange dreams came to him.
column3: Strange dreams came to him.

column2: He thought the old woman took off all his clothes and wrapped him up in a squirrel skin, and that he went about with the other squirrels and guinea pigs, who were all very pleasant and well mannered, and waited on the old woman.
column3: He thought the old woman took off all his clothes and wrapped him up in a squirrel skin, and that he went about with the other squirrels and guinea pigs, who were all very pleasant and well mannered, and waited on the old woman.

column3: First he learned to clean her cocoa nut shoes with oil and to rub them up.

column2: In this way he passed from one kind of service to another, spending a year in each, till in the fourth year he was promoted to the kitchen. Here he worked his way up from under-scullion to head-pastrycook, and reached the greatest perfection.
column3: In this way he passed from one kind of service to another, spending a year in each, till in the fourth year he was promoted to the kitchen. Here he worked his way up from under scullion to head pastrycook, and reached the greatest perfection.

column2: He could make all the most difficult dishes, and two hundred different kinds of patties, soup flavoured with every sort of herb--he had learnt it all, and learnt it well and quickly.
column3: He could make all the most difficult dishes, and two hundred different kinds of patties, soup flavoured with every sort of herb-he had learnt it all, and learnt it well and quickly.

column2: When he had lived seven years with the old woman she ordered him one day, as she was going out, to kill and pluck a chicken, stuff it with herbs, and have it very nicely roasted by the time she got back.
column3: When he had lived seven years with the old woman she ordered him one day, as she was going out, to kill and pluck a chicken, stuff it with herbs, and have it very nicely roasted by the time she got back.

column2: He peeped in and saw a lot of baskets from which came a strong and pleasant smell.

column2: But the smell was so sharp that he began to sneeze again and again, and at last--he woke up!
column3: But the smell was so sharp that he began to sneeze again and again, and at last-he woke up!

column2: There he lay on the old woman's sofa and stared about him in surprise. 'Well, what odd dreams one does have to be sure!' he said to himself. 'Why, I could have sworn I had been a squirrel, a companion of guinea pigs and such creatures, and had become a great cook, too.

column3: The squirrels and guinea pigs ran whimpering after him, as though they would like to go too, and he begged them to come when he reached the door, but they all turned and ran quickly back into the house again.

column3: There sat his mother, with a good deal of fruit still in her baskets, so he felt he could not have slept so very long, but it struck him that she was sad, for she did not call to the passers by, but sat with her head resting on her hand, and as he came nearer he thought she looked paler than usual.

column2: 'What do you want, you hideous dwarf?' she cried; 'get away; I can't bear such tricks.'
column3: 'What do you want, you hideous dwarf?' she cried; 'get away; I can't bear such tricks.'

column2: 'You can't be well.

column3: 'I have said already, get away,' replied Hannah, quite angrily.

column2: 'Just see that frightful dwarf--would you believe that he wants me to think he is my son Jem?'

column3: Then all the market women came round and talked all together and scolded as hard as they could, and said what a shame it was to make game of mrs Hannah, who had never got over the loss of her beautiful boy, who had been stolen from her seven years ago, and they threatened to fall upon Jem and scratch him well if he did not go away at once.

column2: Poor Jem did not know what to make of it all.

column2: Why, what had happened to him?
